C++ Special Math Functions  2.0
sf_ellint.h

1 #ifndef SF_ELLINT_H
2 #define SF_ELLINT_H 1
3 
4 #include <emsr/fp_type_util.h>
5 #include <emsr/detail/sf_ellint.tcc>
6 
7 namespace emsr
8 {
9 
10  // Complete elliptic integrals of the first kind
11 
12  /**
13  * Return the complete elliptic integral of the first kind
14  * @f$ K(k) @f$ for real modulus @c k.
15  *
16  * The complete elliptic integral of the first kind is defined as
17  * @f[
18  * K(k) = F(k,\pi/2) = \int_0^{\pi/2}\frac{d\theta}
19  * {\sqrt{1 - k^2 sin^2\theta}}
20  * @f]
21  * where @f$ F(k,\phi) @f$ is the incomplete elliptic integral of the
22  * first kind and the modulus @f$ |k| <= 1 @f$.
23  * @see ellint_1 for details of the incomplete elliptic function
24  * of the first kind.
25  *
26  * @tparam Tp The floating-point type of the modulus @c k.
27  * @param k The modulus, <tt> abs(k) <= 1 </tt>
28  * @throw std::domain_error if <tt> abs(k) > 1 </tt>.
29  */
30  template<typename Tp>
31  inline emsr::fp_promote_t<Tp>
32  comp_ellint_1(Tp k)
33  {
34  using type = emsr::fp_promote_t<Tp>;
35  return emsr::detail::comp_ellint_1<type>(k);
36  }
37 
38  // Complete elliptic integrals of the second kind
39 
40  /**
41  * Return the complete elliptic integral of the second kind @f$ E(k) @f$
42  * for real modulus @c k.
43  *
44  * The complete elliptic integral of the second kind is defined as
45  * @f[
46  * E(k) = E(k,\pi/2) = \int_0^{\pi/2}\sqrt{1 - k^2 sin^2\theta}
47  * @f]
48  * where @f$ E(k,\phi) @f$ is the incomplete elliptic integral of the
49  * second kind and the modulus @f$ |k| <= 1 @f$.
50  * @see ellint_2 for details of the incomplete elliptic function
51  * of the second kind.
52  *
53  * @tparam Tp The floating-point type of the modulus @c k.
54  * @param k The modulus, @c abs(k) <= 1
55  * @throw std::domain_error if @c abs(k) > 1.
56  */
57  template<typename Tp>
58  inline emsr::fp_promote_t<Tp>
59  comp_ellint_2(Tp k)
60  {
61  using type = emsr::fp_promote_t<Tp>;
62  return emsr::detail::comp_ellint_2<type>(k);
63  }
64 
65  // Complete elliptic integrals of the third kind
66 
67  /**
68  * Return the complete elliptic integral of the third kind
69  * @f$ \Pi(k,\nu) = \Pi(k,\nu,\pi/2) @f$ for real modulus @c k.
70  *
71  * The complete elliptic integral of the third kind is defined as
72  * @f[
73  * \Pi(k,\nu) = \Pi(k,\nu,\pi/2) = \int_0^{\pi/2}
74  * \frac{d\theta}
75  * {(1 - \nu \sin^2\theta)\sqrt{1 - k^2 \sin^2\theta}}
76  * @f]
77  * where @f$ \Pi(k,\nu,\phi) @f$ is the incomplete elliptic integral of the
78  * second kind and the modulus @f$ |k| <= 1 @f$.
79  * @see ellint_3 for details of the incomplete elliptic function
80  * of the third kind.
81  *
82  * @tparam Tp The floating-point type of the modulus @c k.
83  * @tparam _Tpn The floating-point type of the argument @c nu.
84  * @param k The modulus, @c abs(k) <= 1.
85  * @param nu The characteristic.
86  * @throw std::domain_error if @c abs(k) > 1.
87  */
88  template<typename Tp, typename _Tpn>
89  inline emsr::fp_promote_t<Tp, _Tpn>
90  comp_ellint_3(Tp k, _Tpn nu)
91  {
92  using type = emsr::fp_promote_t<Tp, _Tpn>;
93  return emsr::detail::comp_ellint_3<type>(k, nu);
94  }
95 
96  // Incomplete elliptic integrals of the first kind
97 
98  /**
99  * Return the incomplete elliptic integral of the first kind @f$ F(k,\phi) @f$
100  * for @c real modulus @c k and angle @f$ \phi @f$.
101  *
102  * The incomplete elliptic integral of the first kind is defined as
103  * @f[
104  * F(k,\phi) = \int_0^{\phi}\frac{d\theta}
105  * {\sqrt{1 - k^2 sin^2\theta}}
106  * @f]
107  * For @f$ \phi= \pi/2 @f$ this becomes the complete elliptic integral of
108  * the first kind, @f$ K(k) @f$. @see comp_ellint_1.
109  *
110  * @tparam Tp The floating-point type of the modulus @c k.
111  * @tparam _Tpp The floating-point type of the angle @c phi.
112  * @param k The modulus, <tt> abs(k) <= 1 </tt>.
113  * @param phi The integral limit argument in radians.
114  * @throw std::domain_error if <tt> abs(k) > 1 </tt>.
115  */
116  template<typename Tp, typename _Tpp>
117  inline emsr::fp_promote_t<Tp, _Tpp>
118  ellint_1(Tp k, _Tpp phi)
119  {
120  using type = emsr::fp_promote_t<Tp, _Tpp>;
121  return emsr::detail::ellint_1<type>(k, phi);
122  }
123 
124  // Incomplete elliptic integrals of the second kind
125 
126  /**
127  * Return the incomplete elliptic integral of the second kind
128  * @f$ E(k,\phi) @f$.
129  *
130  * The incomplete elliptic integral of the second kind is defined as
131  * @f[
132  * E(k,\phi) = \int_0^{\phi} \sqrt{1 - k^2 sin^2\theta}
133  * @f]
134  * For @f$ \phi= \pi/2 @f$ this becomes the complete elliptic integral of
135  * the second kind, @f$ E(k) @f$. @see comp_ellint_2.
136  *
137  * @tparam Tp The floating-point type of the modulus @c k.
138  * @tparam _Tpp The floating-point type of the angle @c phi.
139  * @param k The modulus, <tt> abs(k) <= 1 </tt>
140  * @param phi The integral limit argument in radians
141  * @return The elliptic function of the second kind.
142  * @throw std::domain_error if <tt> abs(k) > 1 </tt>.
143  */
144  template<typename Tp, typename _Tpp>
145  inline emsr::fp_promote_t<Tp, _Tpp>
146  ellint_2(Tp k, _Tpp phi)
147  {
148  using type = emsr::fp_promote_t<Tp, _Tpp>;
149  return emsr::detail::ellint_2<type>(k, phi);
150  }
151 
152  // Incomplete elliptic integrals of the third kind
153 
154  /**
155  * @brief Return the incomplete elliptic integral of the third kind
156  * @f$ \Pi(k,\nu,\phi) @f$.
157  *
158  * The incomplete elliptic integral of the third kind is defined by:
159  * @f[
160  * \Pi(k,\nu,\phi) = \int_0^{\phi}
161  * \frac{d\theta}
162  * {(1 - \nu \sin^2\theta)
163  * \sqrt{1 - k^2 \sin^2\theta}}
164  * @f]
165  * For @f$ \phi= \pi/2 @f$ this becomes the complete elliptic integral of
166  * the third kind, @f$ \Pi(k,\nu) @f$. @see comp_ellint_3.
167  *
168  * @tparam Tp The floating-point type of the modulus @c k.
169  * @tparam _Tpn The floating-point type of the argument @c nu.
170  * @tparam _Tpp The floating-point type of the angle @c phi.
171  * @param k The modulus, <tt> abs(k) <= 1 </tt>.
172  * @param nu The characteristic.
173  * @param phi The integral limit argument in radians.
174  * @return The elliptic function of the third kind.
175  * @throw std::domain_error if <tt> abs(k) > 1 </tt>.
176  */
177  template<typename Tp, typename _Tpn, typename _Tpp>
178  inline emsr::fp_promote_t<Tp, _Tpn, _Tpp>
179  ellint_3(Tp k, _Tpn nu, _Tpp phi)
180  {
181  using type = emsr::fp_promote_t<Tp, _Tpn, _Tpp>;
182  return emsr::detail::ellint_3<type>(k, nu, phi);
183  }
184 
185  // Complete Carlson elliptic R_F functions
186 
187  /**
188  * Return the complete Carlson elliptic function @f$ R_F(x,y) @f$
189  * for real arguments.
190  *
191  * The complete Carlson elliptic function of the first kind is defined by:
192  * @f[
193  * R_F(x,y) = R_F(x,y,y) = \frac{1}{2} \int_0^\infty
194  * \frac{dt}{(t + x)^{1/2}(t + y)}
195  * @f]
196  *
197  * @param x The first argument.
198  * @param y The second argument.
199  */
200  template<typename _Tx, typename _Ty>
201  inline emsr::fp_promote_t<_Tx, _Ty>
202  comp_ellint_rf(_Tx x, _Ty y)
203  {
204  using type = emsr::fp_promote_t<_Tx, _Ty>;
205  return emsr::detail::comp_ellint_rf<type>(x, y);
206  }
207 
208  // Carlson elliptic R_F functions
209 
210  /**
211  * Return the Carlson elliptic function @f$ R_F(x,y,z) @f$
212  * of the first kind for real arguments.
213  *
214  * The Carlson elliptic function of the first kind is defined by:
215  * @f[
216  * R_F(x,y,z) = \frac{1}{2} \int_0^\infty
217  * \frac{dt}{(t + x)^{1/2}(t + y)^{1/2}(t + z)^{1/2}}
218  * @f]
219  *
220  * @param x The first of three symmetric arguments.
221  * @param y The second of three symmetric arguments.
222  * @param z The third of three symmetric arguments.
223  */
224  template<typename Tp, typename _Up, typename _Vp>
225  inline emsr::fp_promote_t<Tp, _Up, _Vp>
226  ellint_rf(Tp x, _Up y, _Vp z)
227  {
228  using type = emsr::fp_promote_t<Tp, _Up, _Vp>;
229  return emsr::detail::ellint_rf<type>(x, y, z);
230  }
231 
232  // Carlson elliptic R_C functions
233 
234  /**
235  * Return the Carlson elliptic function @f$ R_C(x,y) = R_F(x,y,y) @f$
236  * where @f$ R_F(x,y,z) @f$ is the Carlson elliptic function
237  * of the first kind.
238  *
239  * The Carlson elliptic function is defined by:
240  * @f[
241  * R_C(x,y) = \frac{1}{2} \int_0^\infty
242  * \frac{dt}{(t + x)^{1/2}(t + y)}
243  * @f]
244  *
245  * Based on Carlson's algorithms:
246  * - B. C. Carlson Numer. Math. 33, 1 (1979)
247  * - B. C. Carlson, Special Functions of Applied Mathematics (1977)
248  * - Numerical Recipes in C, 2nd ed, pp. 261-269,
249  * by Press, Teukolsky, Vetterling, Flannery (1992)
250  *
251  * @param x The first argument.
252  * @param y The second argument.
253  */
254  template<typename Tp, typename _Up>
255  inline emsr::fp_promote_t<Tp, _Up>
256  ellint_rc(Tp x, _Up y)
257  {
258  using type = emsr::fp_promote_t<Tp, _Up>;
259  return emsr::detail::ellint_rc<type>(x, y);
260  }
261 
262  // Carlson elliptic R_J functions
263 
264  /**
265  * Return the Carlson elliptic function @f$ R_J(x,y,z,p) @f$
266  * of the third kind.
267  *
268  * The Carlson elliptic function of the third kind is defined by:
269  * @f[
270  * R_J(x,y,z,p) = \frac{3}{2} \int_0^\infty
271  * \frac{dt}{(t + x)^{1/2}(t + y)^{1/2}(t + z)^{1/2}(t + p)}
272  * @f]
273  *
274  * Based on Carlson's algorithms:
275  * - B. C. Carlson Numer. Math. 33, 1 (1979)
276  * - B. C. Carlson, Special Functions of Applied Mathematics (1977)
277  * - Numerical Recipes in C, 2nd ed, pp. 261-269,
278  * by Press, Teukolsky, Vetterling, Flannery (1992)
279  *
280  * @param x The first of three symmetric arguments.
281  * @param y The second of three symmetric arguments.
282  * @param z The third of three symmetric arguments.
283  * @param p The fourth argument.
284  */
285  template<typename Tp, typename _Up, typename _Vp, typename _Wp>
286  inline emsr::fp_promote_t<Tp, _Up, _Vp, _Wp>
287  ellint_rj(Tp x, _Up y, _Vp z, _Wp p)
288  {
289  using type = emsr::fp_promote_t<Tp, _Up, _Vp, _Wp>;
290  return emsr::detail::ellint_rj<type>(x, y, z, p);
291  }
292 
293  // Carlson elliptic R_D functions
294 
295  /**
296  * Return the Carlson elliptic function of the second kind
297  * @f$ R_D(x,y,z) = R_J(x,y,z,z) @f$ where
298  * @f$ R_J(x,y,z,p) @f$ is the Carlson elliptic function
299  * of the third kind.
300  *
301  * The Carlson elliptic function of the second kind is defined by:
302  * @f[
303  * R_D(x,y,z) = \frac{3}{2} \int_0^\infty
304  * \frac{dt}{(t + x)^{1/2}(t + y)^{1/2}(t + z)^{3/2}}
305  * @f]
306  *
307  * Based on Carlson's algorithms:
308  * - B. C. Carlson Numer. Math. 33, 1 (1979)
309  * - B. C. Carlson, Special Functions of Applied Mathematics (1977)
310  * - Numerical Recipes in C, 2nd ed, pp. 261-269,
311  * by Press, Teukolsky, Vetterling, Flannery (1992)
312  *
313  * @param x The first of two symmetric arguments.
314  * @param y The second of two symmetric arguments.
315  * @param z The third argument.
316  */
317  template<typename Tp, typename _Up, typename _Vp>
318  inline emsr::fp_promote_t<Tp, _Up, _Vp>
319  ellint_rd(Tp x, _Up y, _Vp z)
320  {
321  using type = emsr::fp_promote_t<Tp, _Up, _Vp>;
322  return emsr::detail::ellint_rd<type>(x, y, z);
323  }
324 
325  // Complete Carlson elliptic R_G functions
326 
327  /**
328  * Return the complete Carlson elliptic function @f$ R_G(x,y) @f$
329  * for real arguments.
330  *
331  * The complete Carlson elliptic function is defined by:
332  * @f[
333  * R_G(x,y) = R_G(x,y,y) = \frac{1}{4} \int_0^\infty
334  * dt t (t + x)^{-1/2}(t + y)^{-1}
335  * \left(\frac{x}{t + x} + \frac{2y}{t + y}\right)
336  * @f]
337  *
338  * @param x The first argument.
339  * @param y The second argument.
340  */
341  template<typename _Tx, typename _Ty>
342  inline emsr::fp_promote_t<_Tx, _Ty>
343  comp_ellint_rg(_Tx x, _Ty y)
344  {
345  using type = emsr::fp_promote_t<_Tx, _Ty>;
346  return emsr::detail::comp_ellint_rg<type>(x, y);
347  }
348 
349  // Carlson elliptic R_G functions
350 
351  /**
352  * Return the symmetric Carlson elliptic function of the second kind
353  * @f$ R_G(x,y,z) @f$.
354  *
355  * The Carlson symmetric elliptic function of the second kind is defined by:
356  * @f[
357  * R_G(x,y,z) = \frac{1}{4} \int_0^\infty
358  * dt t [(t + x)(t + y)(t + z)]^{-1/2}
359  * (\frac{x}{t + x} + \frac{y}{t + y} + \frac{z}{t + z})
360  * @f]
361  *
362  * Based on Carlson's algorithms:
363  * - B. C. Carlson Numer. Math. 33, 1 (1979)
364  * - B. C. Carlson, Special Functions of Applied Mathematics (1977)
365  * - Numerical Recipes in C, 2nd ed, pp. 261-269,
366  * by Press, Teukolsky, Vetterling, Flannery (1992)
367  *
368  * @param x The first of three symmetric arguments.
369  * @param y The second of three symmetric arguments.
370  * @param z The third of three symmetric arguments.
371  */
372  template<typename Tp, typename _Up, typename _Vp>
373  inline emsr::fp_promote_t<Tp, _Up, _Vp>
374  ellint_rg(Tp x, _Up y, _Vp z)
375  {
376  using type = emsr::fp_promote_t<Tp, _Up, _Vp>;
377  return emsr::detail::ellint_rg<type>(x, y, z);
378  }
379 
380  // Jacobi zeta functions.
381 
382  /**
383  * Return the Jacobi zeta function of @c k and @f$ \phi @f$.
384  *
385  * The Jacobi zeta function is defined by
386  * @f[
387  * Z(m,\phi) = E(m,\phi) - \frac{E(m)F(m,\phi)}{K(m)}
388  * @f]
389  * where @f$ E(m,\phi) @f$ is the elliptic function of the second kind,
390  * @f$ E(m) @f$ is the complete ellitic function of the second kind,
391  * and @f$ F(m,\phi) @f$ is the elliptic function of the first kind.
392  *
393  * @tparam _Tk the real type of the modulus
394  * @tparam _Tphi the real type of the angle limit
395  * @param k The modulus
396  * @param phi The angle
397  */
398  template<typename _Tk, typename _Tphi>
399  inline emsr::fp_promote_t<_Tk, _Tphi>
400  jacobi_zeta(_Tk k, _Tphi phi)
401  {
402  using type = emsr::fp_promote_t<_Tk, _Tphi>;
403  return emsr::detail::jacobi_zeta<type>(k, phi);
404  }
405 
406  // Heuman lambda functions.
407 
408  /**
409  * Return the Heuman lambda function @f$ \Lambda(k,\phi) @f$
410  * of modulus @c k and angular limit @f$ \phi @f$.
411  *
412  * The complete Heuman lambda function is defined by
413  * @f[
414  * \Lambda(k,\phi) = \frac{F(1-m,\phi)}{K(1-m)}
415  * + \frac{2}{\pi} K(m) Z(1-m,\phi)
416  * @f]
417  * where @f$ m = k^2 @f$, @f$ K(k) @f$ is the complete elliptic function
418  * of the first kind, and @f$ Z(k,\phi) @f$ is the Jacobi zeta function.
419  *
420  * @tparam _Tk the floating-point type of the modulus
421  * @tparam _Tphi the floating-point type of the angular limit argument
422  * @param k The modulus
423  * @param phi The angle
424  */
425  template<typename _Tk, typename _Tphi>
426  inline emsr::fp_promote_t<_Tk, _Tphi>
427  heuman_lambda(_Tk k, _Tphi phi)
428  {
429  using type = emsr::fp_promote_t<_Tk, _Tphi>;
430  return emsr::detail::heuman_lambda<type>(k, phi);
431  }
432 
433  // Complete Legendre elliptic integral D.
434 
435  /**
436  * Return the complete Legendre elliptic integral @f$ D(k) @f$
437  * of real modulus @c k.
438  *
439  * The complete Legendre elliptic integral D is defined by
440  * @f[
441  * D(k) = \int_0^{\pi/2} \frac{\sin^2\theta d\theta}{\sqrt{1-k^2sin2\theta}}
442  * @f]
443  *
444  * @tparam _Tk The type of the modulus @c k
445  * @param k The modulus <tt>-1 <= k <= +1</tt>
446  */
447  template<typename _Tk>
448  inline emsr::fp_promote_t<_Tk>
449  comp_ellint_d(_Tk k)
450  {
451  using type = emsr::fp_promote_t<_Tk>;
452  return emsr::detail::comp_ellint_d<type>(k);
453  }
454 
455  // Legendre elliptic integrals D.
456 
457  /**
458  * Return the incomplete Legendre elliptic integral @f$ D(k,\phi) @f$
459  * of real modulus @c k and angular limit @f$ \phi @f$.
460  *
461  * The Legendre elliptic integral D is defined by
462  * @f[
463  * D(k,\phi) = \int_0^\phi
464  * \frac{\sin^2\theta d\theta}{\sqrt{1-k^2sin^2\theta}}
465  * @f]
466  *
467  * @param k The modulus <tt>-1 <= k <= +1</tt>
468  * @param phi The angle
469  */
470  template<typename _Tk, typename _Tphi>
471  inline emsr::fp_promote_t<_Tk, _Tphi>
472  ellint_d(_Tk k, _Tphi phi)
473  {
474  using type = emsr::fp_promote_t<_Tk, _Tphi>;
475  return emsr::detail::ellint_d<type>(k, phi);
476  }
477 
478  // Bulirsch elliptic integrals of the first kind.
479 
480  /**
481  * Return the Bulirsch elliptic integral @f$ el1(x,k_c) @f$
482  * of the first kind of real tangent limit @c x
483  * and complementary modulus @f$ k_c @f$.
484  *
485  * The Bulirsch elliptic integral of the first kind is defined by
486  * @f[
487  * el1(x,k_c) = el2(x,k_c,1,1) = \int_0^{\arctan x} \frac{1+1\tan^2\theta}
488  * {\sqrt{(1+\tan^2\theta)(1+k_c^2\tan^2\theta)}}d\theta
489  * @f]
490  *
491  * @param x The tangent of the angular integration limit
492  * @param k_c The complementary modulus @f$ k_c = \sqrt{1 - k^2} @f$
493  */
494  template<typename Tp, typename _Tk>
495  inline emsr::fp_promote_t<Tp, _Tk>
496  ellint_el1(Tp x, _Tk k_c)
497  {
498  using type = emsr::fp_promote_t<Tp, _Tk>;
499  return emsr::detail::ellint_el1<type>(x, k_c);
500  }
501 
502  // Bulirsch elliptic integrals of the second kind.
503 
504  /**
505  * Return the Bulirsch elliptic integral of the second kind
506  * @f$ el2(x,k_c,a,b) @f$.
507  *
508  * The Bulirsch elliptic integral of the second kind is defined by
509  * @f[
510  * el2(x,k_c,a,b) = \int_0^{\arctan x} \frac{a+b\tan^2\theta}
511  * {\sqrt{(1+\tan^2\theta)(1+k_c^2\tan^2\theta)}}d\theta
512  * @f]
513  *
514  * @param x The tangent of the angular integration limit
515  * @param k_c The complementary modulus @f$ k_c = \sqrt{1 - k^2} @f$
516  * @param a The parameter
517  * @param b The parameter
518  */
519  template<typename Tp, typename _Tk, typename _Ta, typename _Tb>
520  inline emsr::fp_promote_t<Tp, _Tk, _Ta, _Tb>
521  ellint_el2(Tp x, _Tk k_c, _Ta a, _Tb b)
522  {
523  using type = emsr::fp_promote_t<Tp, _Tk, _Ta, _Tb>;
524  return emsr::detail::ellint_el2<type>(x, k_c, a, b);
525  }
526 
527  // Bulirsch elliptic integrals of the third kind.
528 
529  /**
530  * Return the Bulirsch elliptic integral of the third kind
531  * @f$ el3(x,k_c,p) @f$ of real tangent limit @c x,
532  * complementary modulus @f$ k_c @f$, and parameter @c p.
533  *
534  * The Bulirsch elliptic integral of the third kind is defined by
535  * @f[
536  * el3(x,k_c,p) = \int_0^{\arctan x} \frac{d\theta}
537  * {(cos^2\theta+p\sin^2\theta)\sqrt{cos^2\theta+k_c^2\sin^2\theta}}
538  * @f]
539  *
540  * @param x The tangent of the angular integration limit
541  * @param k_c The complementary modulus @f$ k_c = \sqrt{1 - k^2} @f$
542  * @param p The paramenter
543  */
544  template<typename _Tx, typename _Tk, typename Tp>
545  inline emsr::fp_promote_t<_Tx, _Tk, Tp>
546  ellint_el3(_Tx x, _Tk k_c, Tp p)
547  {
548  using type = emsr::fp_promote_t<_Tx, _Tk, Tp>;
549  return emsr::detail::ellint_el3<type>(x, k_c, p);
550  }
551 
552  // Bulirsch complete elliptic integrals.
553 
554  /**
555  * Return the Bulirsch complete elliptic integral @f$ cel(k_c,p,a,b) @f$
556  * of real complementary modulus @f$ k_c @f$, and parameters @c p,
557  * @c a, and @c b.
558  *
559  * The Bulirsch complete elliptic integral is defined by
560  * @f[
561  * cel(k_c,p,a,b)=\int_0^{\pi/2}
562  * \frac{a\cos^2\theta + b\sin^2\theta}{cos^2\theta + p\sin^2\theta}
563  * \frac{d\theta}{\sqrt{cos^2\theta + k_c^2\sin^2\theta}}
564  * @f]
565  *
566  * @param k_c The complementary modulus @f$ k_c = \sqrt{1 - k^2} @f$
567  * @param p The parameter
568  * @param a The parameter
569  * @param b The parameter
570  */
571  template<typename _Tk, typename Tp, typename _Ta, typename _Tb>
572  inline emsr::fp_promote_t<_Tk, Tp, _Ta, _Tb>
573  ellint_cel(_Tk k_c, Tp p, _Ta a, _Tb b)
574  {
575  using type = emsr::fp_promote_t<_Tk, Tp, _Ta, _Tb>;
576  return emsr::detail::ellint_cel<type>(k_c, p, a, b);
577  }
578 
579 } // namespace emsr
580 
581 #endif // SF_ELLINT_H
